web-research.tools: - `web_quickSearch` → fast lookup: news, facts, specific resources - `web_deepResearch` → comprehensive multi-source research (30-120s, ~$0.10-0.20) - `web_fetchContent` → get full content from URLs
web-research.when-to-use:
QUICK SEARCH: facts, news, specific links, verification - "Bitcoin price", "React docs link", "latest AI news" - Use: category: "news", recentOnly: true for news
DEEP RESEARCH: blog posts, comprehensive pages, multi-perspective topics - "Write about sustainable fashion", "research AI trends" - Returns structured report with citations
web-research.workflow: Creating content with research: 1. web_deepResearch({topic, sections, includeStatistics}) → wait 30-120s 2. Use report.content and citations in cms_createPost 3. Include sources in final content
web-research.examples:
**Quick lookup:** "Latest EV news" → web_quickSearch({query: "electric vehicle news 2025", category: "news", recentOnly: true, numResults: 5}) → Display results with titles and snippets
**Deep research for blog:** "Write about sustainable fashion, research the web" → 1. web_deepResearch({topic: "sustainable fashion trends 2025", sections: ["overview", "trends", "innovations"], includeStatistics: true}) 2. Wait for completion → {report: {summary, content}, citations} 3. cms_createPost using research content, cite sources
**Fetch URL content:** "Summarize this article: https://example.com/article" → web_fetchContent({urls: ["https://..."], includeSummary: true, summaryQuery: "main points"}) → Return summary to user
web-research.tips: - Specific queries work better: "sustainable fashion trends 2025" > "fashion" - Include statistics for data-driven content - Always cite sources in generated content
